thread.title_full: Guess Which Carrier Won SkyTrax’s Top World Airline Awards for 2015?

author: Benet Wilson
title: Guess Which Carrier Won SkyTrax’s Top World Airline Awards for 2015?
text:
A Qatar Airways flight attendant. The winner of Skytrax’s World Airline Awards’ Airline of the Year for 2015 is Doha-based Qatar Airways, for the third time in five years. And we also take a look at the winners in different SkyTrax carriers.
Travelers from around the world fill out the world’s largest airline passenger satisfaction survey to decide the winners. The survey was operated online between September 2014 and May 2015, with nearly 20 million customer surveys completed across a range of survey topics.
More than 105 different nationalities participated in the customer satisfaction survey, which covered 245 airlines, from large international airlines to smaller domestic carriers. The surveys measure standards across 41 key performance indicators of airline front-line product and service.
The world's top 10 airlines in 2015 were:
Qatar Airways
Singapore Airlines
Cathay Pacific Airways
Turkish Airlines
Emirates
Etihad Airways
ANA All Nippon Airways
Garuda Indonesia
EVA Air
Qantas Airways
Qatar Airways not only won airline of the year, it also won best airline in the Middle East and best business class seat. During the 2014-15 period, the Doha-based carrier moved to a new home at Hamad International Airport and welcomed the Airbus A380 super jumbo and the Airbus A350 XWB aircraft into its fleet.
In the 2015 awards, Virgin America not only retained the awards for Best Low Cost Airline in North America and Best Airline Staff Service in North America, but was also named the overall Best Airline in North America. The San Francisco-based airline was lauded by passengers for its high staff service quality.
Singapore Airlines won for best airline in Asia, best business class and best first class seat. The Changi Airport-based flag carrier finished second in the global survey, beating regional rival (and 2014 winner) Cathay Pacific Airways and All Nippon Airways in the Asia region category.
The carrier also won World's Best Business Class, followed by Qatar Airways and Cathay Pacific.
For the fifth year in a row, Turkish Airlines was named Best Airline in Europe. It also won awards for World's Best Business Class Lounge and Best Business Class Lounge Dining. It was win number six for Hainan Airlines, named Best Airline in China. It also won the prize for Best Airline Staff in China.
South African Airways was named Best Airline in Africa, while AirAsia was once again named as World's Best Low Cost Airline, beating out eight others in the category. It also won Best Low Cost Airline in Asia, and has been the only recipient of this award since it was introduced in 2009. Qantas won for Best Airline in the Australia/Pacific or the third consecutive year and Best Business Class Comfort Amenities, beating out Qatar Airways and Hainan Airlines.
Low-cost carrier Norwegian took the inaugural prize for the World's Best Long-Haul Low-Cost Airline. This new award category was unveiled to reflect the growing number of low-cost airlines offering long-haul flights. Passengers were impressed by the fleet of new Boeing 787 Dreamliner jets used on routes across the Atlantic and into Asia. For the third consecutive year, it also won Best Low Cost Airline in Europe, beating easyJet and Germanwings.
LAN Airlines scored a double victory in South America for the 2015 Skytrax World Airline Awards. For the second year in a row, the carrier was named Best Airline in South America and Best Airline Staff in South America.
Finally, Air France was named the World's Most Improved Airline. Passengers rewarded the Paris-based carrier for its "Best & Beyond" strategy, which included upgrades on items including seats, and lounges. It also won for Best First Class Lounge Dining forthe second year in a row for its Chef Alain Ducasse-inspired menu and lounge dining experience.
